extractions.title: Investigating the Shared Genetic Architecture Between Kidney Function and Alzheimer's Disease Across Ancestries

extractions.method_detail: Reported in context of local correlations. Paper used LDSC, cond/conjFDR, and LAVA; this h2 is reported alongside LAVA local-correlation results (likely a LAVA local or regional heritability estimate), but the text does not explicitly name the specific estimation method for the h2 value.
extractions.source_text: In EUR, 52 regions showed significant local correlations (Bonferroni‐corrected), and heritability (AD: h² = 0.05, p ≈ 0.025; eGFR: h² = 0.10, p < 1E‐10).
extractions.evidence_html: ...ificant (r g values ≈ 0.07) in both ancestries, with regions of strong local correlations observed. In EUR, 52 regions showed significant local correlations (Bonferroni‐corrected), and heritability (AD: h² = 0.05, p ≈ 0.025; eGFR: h² = 0.10, p < 1E‐10). These regions exhibited balanced bidirectional correlations (26 loci each; positive range: 0.32 to ...

extractions.title: Integrated genetic analysis of Alzheimer's disease and stroke subtypes: insights from LDSC, PLACO, and MR studies.

extractions.method_detail: Quoted in Discussion as a literature estimate (refs 41,42). Original method for this 24% estimate is not specified in the text. The present paper used LDSC for analyses but did not report its own SNP-heritability point estimate for AD.
extractions.ancestry: predominantly European (LD scores calculated from European 1000 Genomes reference; GWAS cohorts largely European)
extractions.source_text: Complex diseases like AD and IS are largely influenced by the collective impact of numerous common genetic variants, with each variant contributing a minor portion of the overall risk [ 40 ], it is es
extractions.evidence_html: ...mber of variants ( HDAC9 ) affecting the specific stroke subtypes have been identified [ 38 , 39 ]. Complex diseases like AD and IS are largely influenced by the collective impact of numerous common genetic variants, with each variant contributing a minor portion of the overall risk [ 40 ], it is estimated that these common genetic variants account for about 24% of the variance in AD and about 18% in stroke [ 41 , 42 ]. QQ plot analysis confirmed the quality and potential bias of the GWAS results, revealing that the o...

extractions.method_detail: Quoted in Discussion as a literature estimate (refs 41,42). Original method for this 18% estimate is not specified in the text. The present paper used LDSC for analyses but did not report its own SNP-heritability point estimate for stroke.
extractions.ancestry: predominantly European (LD scores calculated from European 1000 Genomes reference; GWAS cohorts largely European)

Complex diseases like AD and IS are largely influenced by the collective impact of numerous common genetic variants, with each variant contributing a minor portion of the overall risk [ 40 ], it is estimated that these common genetic variants account for about 24% of the variance in AD and about 18% in stroke [ 41 , 42 ]. extractions.title: Alzheimer disease is (sometimes) highly heritable: Drivers of variation in heritability estimates for binary traits, a systematic review.

extractions.method_detail: Lee et al. (2013) GCTA estimate; 499,757 SNPs (less dense genotyping noted).
extractions.source_text: The resulting LOAD heritability estimate of 24% was based on a sample of 7,139 participants (3,290 cases, 3,849 controls) that included both elderly screened and population controls [71,72].

extractions.method_detail: Ridge et al. (2013) using ADGC dataset (imputed to HapMap II; ~2,042,116 SNPs after QC).
extractions.source_text: Concurrent ly, Ridge et al. (2013) leveraged the Alzheimer’s Disease Genetics Consortium (ADGC) dataset, including 10,922 individuals (5,708 cases, 5,214 controls), and estimated a higher heritability

extractions.method_detail: Ridge et al. (2016) update including 30 ADGC studies; noted use of many SNPs (8,712,879) and requirement for non-missing data across known AD genes.
extractions.source_text: A 2016 update included data from 30 studies within the ADGC, and the heritability estimate increased to 53%. This study included only 9,699 individuals (3,877 cases, 5,822 controls) [75].

extractions.method_detail: Lo et al. (2019) age-stratified GCTA estimate (>80 years).
extractions.source_text: Lo et al. (2019) with a much larger sample size of unrelated individuals estimated a higher heritability for participants >80 years of age (n = 5,198; h2 = 24.1%) compared with those aged 60–69 years

extractions.method_detail: Lo et al. (2019) age-stratified GCTA estimate (60–69 years).
extractions.source_text: Lo et al. (2019) ... those aged 60–69 years of age (n = 12,698; h2 = 16.9%).

extractions.method_detail: Lo et al. (2019) sex-specific GCTA estimate (reported in review).
extractions.source_text: Differences by sex were subtler with a slightly higher LOAD heritability among women (21.5%) compared with men (19.5%) [78].

extractions.method_detail: Lo et al. (2019) sex-specific GCTA estimate (reported in review).
extractions.source_text: Differences by sex were subtler with a slightly higher LOAD heritability among women (21.5%) compared with men (19.5%) [78].

extractions.method_detail: Wang et al. (2021) analysis of 2-phase ADGC data with cohort indicators; reported heritability ~21%.
extractions.source_text: Wang et al. (2021) similarly incorporated cohort indicators in their analysis of 2-phase ADGC data, obtaining an expected comparable heritability estimate of 21% [78].

extractions.trait: Late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (LOAD) — histopathologically confirmed cohorts (range across cohorts)
extractions.method_detail: Baker et al. (2023) reported histopathologically confirmed heritability across five cohorts of 31% - 57% using a consistent model with a 5% liability threshold (this entry records the lower bound of the reported range).
extractions.source_text: Baker et al (2023) illustrated this by demonstrating that the histopathologically confirmed LOAD yielded higher heritability estimates (31% - 57%) compared to clinically diagnosed LOAD (12% - 32%) whe

extractions.trait: Late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (LOAD) — histopathologically confirmed cohorts (range across cohorts)
extractions.method_detail: Baker et al. (2023) reported histopathologically confirmed heritability across five cohorts of 31% - 57% using a consistent model with a 5% liability threshold (this entry records the upper bound of the reported range).
extractions.source_text: Baker et al (2023) illustrated this by demonstrating that the histopathologically confirmed LOAD yielded higher heritability estimates (31% - 57%) compared to clinically diagnosed LOAD (12% - 32%) whe

extractions.trait: Late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (LOAD) — clinically diagnosed cohorts (range across cohorts)
extractions.method_detail: Baker et al. (2023) reported clinically diagnosed LOAD heritability across five cohorts of 12% - 32% using a consistent model with a 5% liability threshold (this entry records the lower bound of the reported range).
extractions.source_text: Baker et al (2023) ... clinically diagnosed LOAD (12% - 32%) when applying a consistent model with a 5% liability threshold to five independent cohorts [79].

extractions.trait: Late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (LOAD) — clinically diagnosed cohorts (range across cohorts)
extractions.method_detail: Baker et al. (2023) reported clinically diagnosed LOAD heritability across five cohorts of 12% - 32% using a consistent model with a 5% liability threshold (this entry records the upper bound of the reported range).
extractions.source_text: Baker et al (2023) ... clinically diagnosed LOAD (12% - 32%) when applying a consistent model with a 5% liability threshold to five independent cohorts [79].

extractions.method_detail: Zheng et al. (2017) reported an observed-scale LDSC heritability estimate of 6.88% (based on Lambert et al. 2013 stage 1 summary statistics).
extractions.source_text: Zheng et al. (2017) ... reported observed-scale heritability estimates of 6.88% ... [87].

extractions.method_detail: Chen et al. (2021) reported an observed-scale LDSC heritability estimate of 6.80% (review citation).
extractions.source_text: Zheng et al. (2017) and Chen et al. (2021) reported similar observed-scale heritability estimates of 6.88% and 6.80%, respectively [87,89].

extractions.method_detail: Brainstorm Consortium (2018) liability-scale LDSC estimate using a population prevalence of 17% for transformation.
extractions.source_text: In contrast, the Brainstorm Consortium et al. (2018) provided a markedly different liability-scale heritability estimate of 13%, using a population prevalence of 17% for the transformation [88].

extractions.method_detail: Kunkle et al. (2019) stage-1 summary statistics LDSC estimate reported as 7% in a re-evaluation context.
extractions.source_text: As an example, heritability estimates using data from Kunkle et al (2019) increased from 7% with LDSC (Table 3) to 21% using LDAK [99].

extractions.method_detail: Wightman et al. (2021) GWAS (n = 761,702; 43,725 cases, 717,979 controls) produced an LDSC-based heritability reported in review as 3.1% (reference [26]).
extractions.source_text: Wightman et al. (2021) ... resulting in a sample size of 761,702 (43,725 cases, 717,979 controls) and its own heritability estimate based on this LOAD GWAS [26]. (Earlier the review states the range i

extractions.trait: Late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (LOAD) — Kunkle dataset, LDAK re-evaluation
extractions.method_detail: LDAK re-evaluation (reference [99]) of Kunkle et al. (2019) data increased estimate from 7% (LDSC) to 21% (LDAK).
extractions.source_text: As an example, heritability estimates using data from Kunkle et al (2019) increased from 7% with LDSC ( Table 3 ) to 21% using LDAK [99].

extractions.trait: Late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (LOAD) — re-evaluation GCTA lower bound
extractions.method_detail: Re-evaluation across multiple datasets (reference [97]) using a consistent population prevalence of 5%; reported GCTA estimates ranged 25%–31% (this entry = lower bound).
extractions.source_text: With a consistent population prevalence of 5%: ... the GCTA estimates were higher at 25% to 31% [97].

extractions.trait: Late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (LOAD) — re-evaluation GCTA upper bound
extractions.method_detail: Re-evaluation across multiple datasets (reference [97]) using a consistent population prevalence of 5%; reported GCTA estimates ranged 25%–31% (this entry = upper bound).
extractions.source_text: With a consistent population prevalence of 5%: ... the GCTA estimates were higher at 25% to 31% [97].

extractions.trait: Late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (LOAD) — re-evaluation LDSC lower bound
extractions.method_detail: Re-evaluation (reference [97]) using consistent prevalence of 5% reported LDSC range 9%–17% (this entry = lower bound).
extractions.source_text: With a consistent population prevalence of 5%: the LOAD heritability estimates using LDSC ranged from 9% to 17% [97].

extractions.trait: Late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (LOAD) — re-evaluation LDSC upper bound
extractions.method_detail: Re-evaluation (reference [97]) using consistent prevalence of 5% reported LDSC range 9%–17% (this entry = upper bound).
extractions.source_text: With a consistent population prevalence of 5%: the LOAD heritability estimates using LDSC ranged from 9% to 17% [97].

extractions.trait: Late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (LOAD) — re-evaluation LDSC wide-range example
extractions.method_detail: Re-evaluation (reference [98]) reported an LDSC range 3%–42% using consistent prevalence of 5% (this entry = lower bound).
extractions.source_text: the LOAD heritability estimates using LDSC ranged from 3% to 42% [98].

extractions.trait: Late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (LOAD) — re-evaluation LDSC wide-range example (upper)
extractions.method_detail: Re-evaluation (reference [98]) reported an LDSC range 3%–42% using consistent prevalence of 5% (this entry = upper bound).
extractions.source_text: the LOAD heritability estimates using LDSC ranged from 3% to 42% [98].
